Description, Wordsworth’s chosen label for the second, third, and fourth editions, was in ways more accurate, though the Guide never confines its task to merely “describing” the region.

Another feature distinguishing Wordsworth’s essay from its forerunners is the pioneering case it makes for preserving the ecological, aesthetic, and social health of the Lake District. Even while promoting the region’s charms, it conveys a fear that newcomers may love the region to death. As noted above, Wordsworth writes as a Lake District local, but he also writes to locals—especially to wealthy landowners who have recently arrived. The title page of the 1835 edition advertises this as a book “for the use of Tourists and Residents,” and all stand-alone versions included the bluntly subtitled section on “Changes, and Rules of Taste for Preventing their Bad Effects.” Whether descanting on the ideal color for homes, the traditional shape of vernacular chimneys, or the sensible placement of trees, Wordsworth often takes a view that transcends the limits of private property. He argues that, in a special moral sense, the countryside belongs to everyone, regardless of who might legally own a particular corner of it. Most famously, his pronouncement that the Lake District should be regarded as “a sort of national property, in which every man has a right and interest who has an eye to perceive and a heart to enjoy” (para. 93) offers an original vision for the idea of the national park.

(77)
On Wordsworth as founding figure for national parks, see Stephen Gill, Wordsworth and the Victorians (Oxford: Clarendon, 1998), 260.
This passage would inspire the founders of Britain’s National Trust, early proponents of national parks in Britain and America, and the 1951 establishment of Lake District National Park, the largest designated region in England and now a UNESCO World Heritage site. As Peter Bicknell suggests, “whether we agree with [Wordsworth] or not, he has fundamentally changed the way we all look at the natural world.”
(78)
Bicknell, Illustrated Wordsworth’s Guide to the Lakes, 7.

In gradually reworking and repurposing his Guide, Wordsworth came to consider it less an autonomous work than part of his larger literary and philosophical project. Where other topographical writers might refer to a painting, Wordsworth usually quotes poetry, not infrequently his own.

(79)
See Julia S. Carlson, “Prose Mesurée in the Lakes Tour and Guide: Quoting and Recalibrating English Blank Verse,” European Romantic Review 20, no. 2 (April 2009): 227–36.
Throughout the Guide, he imports verse not merely for vanity or ornamentation; rather, he grasps for the most evocative language at hand, whether in the form of a lyric, a passage from the Excursion, or a few lines from such unpublished works as “Home at Grasmere” or The Prelude. In so doing, Wordsworth insists that poetry is an authoritative mode of description. His quotations become both illustrations and occasions for heightened focus. Sometimes they also model emotional reactions, encouraging readers to translate the writer’s observations into the realms of personal sensation and reflection.

Within the larger history of travel writing, the Guide also expands the trend of blending poetry with topographical prose. By Victorian times, this potent combination would not only make reading poetry essential to travelers’ landscape explorations but would also produce a thoroughly literary geography, converting the Lake District into the “Wordsworthshire” of literary tourists.

(80)
“Wordsworthshire” seems to have been coined by Harvard professor James Russell Lowell (see the unsigned biographical sketch he contributed to The Poetical Works of William Wordsworth [7 vols., Boston: Little, Brown, and Company, 1854, xxxviii], material later reworked as “Wordsworth” in Among My Books, 2nd Series [Boston: James R. Osgood, 1876, 240]). However, the term is essentially synonymous with “Wordsworth Country” and other common designations of the Lake District’s literary landscape that developed across the nineteenth and into the early twentieth century. Compare “Scot…
After all, Wordsworth’s self-quotation performs anthology-making functions, making it difficult to disentangle the long-range impact of his Guide from the reverberations of his poems. In the end, Wordsworth, his verses, and the terrain he celebrated became inseparable in the public imagination. The increasing popularity of Wordsworth’s poetry from the 1820s through the 1840s mirrored, and probably owed something to, the growing accessibility of the Lake District as tourist terrain. Meanwhile, this tourism, abetted by marketing savvy on the poet’s and his publishers’ parts, helped consolidate Wordsworth’s Victorian authorial persona.

Considering the wide-ranging impact the Guide has had on literary and environmental thought over its first two-plus centuries, there’s ample cause for gratitude that Joseph Wilkinson turned up in the spring of 1809 with an offer that at last persuaded Wordsworth to overcome his anxieties about doing justice to “a theme so boundless and sublime as this beautiful region” (letter 2).

(81)
Letters, 2:271.
However splenetic he grew while finishing its earliest incarnation, the resulting essay still impresses with its earnest affection for its subject. There are moments in the Guide when the literature of knowledge modulates into the literature of power: striking metaphors; accounts of the "magical" effects of reflection, light and mist; expeditions into the clouds; and even excursions back in time. Other passages dwell on the small and often overlooked—lichens, wildflowers, ferns, gravel. Such descriptions capture in prose the “poetry of nature” for which Wordsworth remains beloved. In short, the book promotes "imagination," defined by Wordsworth in his note to “The Thorn” as “the faculty which produces impressive effects out of simple elements.”
(82)
The “poetry of nature” phrase originates in Coleridge’s account of the genesis of Lyrical Ballads: “During the first year that Mr. Wordsworth and I were neighbours, our conversations turned frequently on the two cardinal points of poetry, the power of exciting the sympathy of the reader by a faithful adherence to the truth of nature, and the power of giving the interest of novelty by the modifying colours of imagination. The sudden charm, which accidents of light and shade, which moonlight or sunset diffused over a known and familiar landscape, appeared to represent the practicability of combi…
It aims to transform the tourist experience into a higher spiritual exercise, inviting visitors to read the landscape as they have learned to read Wordsworth’s poems.

Of course, the history of the Guide’s influence hardly ends with the editions published during his lifetime. Victorian guidebooks commonly referenced it, so that many of its principles, absorbed and ultimately taken for granted, came to affect readers indirectly. Lake District tourism and its associated literature continued to grow rapidly after the poet’s death, encouraged by improved transportation to the gateway towns, the emergence of photography, and the unflagging enthusiasm of many writers, walkers, tour promoters, artists, and conservationists, notable Wordsworthians among them. While Wordsworth would have been pleased by the expansion of his reputation and influence, he likely would have felt some discomfort about the commercialization of “Wordsworth Country.” Late in his life, he had famously protested the construction of the Kendal and Windermere Railway, fearing that mass tourism would degrade the Lake District’s “character of seclusion and retirement.”

(83)
See his letters to the Morning Post, published together in slightly revised and expanded form as the pamphlet Kendal and Windermere Railway: Two Letters Re-printed from The Morning Post (1844), 6.

Yet, despite the irony of a man so skeptical of tourism writing a guidebook, Wordsworth had a lifelong passion for introducing others to the beauties of his native region and a growing awareness of how his works helped produce the demand for tourist infrastructure. While his second railway letter reminded the coming hordes that “there are temples of Nature, temples built by the Almighty, which have . . . claim to be left unviolated,” he never expected or desired to keep the Lakes to himself.

(84)
Kendal and Windermere Railway, 19.
In candid moments he may even have appreciated the synchronicity of the railway and his appointment as Poet Laureate arriving together in the 1840s. He would now have to accept the crowds at Windermere along with his fan mail and the pilgrims finding their way to Rydal Mount—all natural consequences of an appreciative readership. The Guide thus leaves us with a paradox, and it may be said to have come up short in some of its rhetorical aims. Still, signs of the impact of Wordsworth’s taste-shaping efforts, his conservation ethic, and his love of nature abound even now in the Lake District and beyond.

Notes

1. As detailed below, Wordsworth’s essay appeared under various names before he titled his fifth, and final, revised edition of 1835 A Guide through the District of the Lakes in the North of England. The shorthand Guide to the Lakes became common in the late nineteenth century and even more firmly fixed with Ernest De Sélincourt’s 1906 edition, Wordsworth’s Guide to the Lakes (London: Henry Frowde). Keeping with convention, then, we refer to all editions as the Guide to the Lakes (or simply the Guide). Given that William Wordsworth is the principal focus of this edition, “Wordsworth” designates him throughout, though occasionally we use his first name in passages mentioning multiple Wordsworths. When referring to Dorothy Wordsworth, we use her given name to avoid confusion. [back]

For a fuller list of commentaries on the Guide, see this edition’s Annotated Bibliography. [back]

The Trust’s website includes a biographical sketch of Wilkinson that borrows heavily from Powell and Hebron and a thoughtful 2015 appraisal of Wilkinson by the historian Jenny Uglow. [back]

22. In his 1797 travel diary, Johnson Grant notes how, while at “Armathwaite,” his party was “entertained by many paintings and prints, collected by Mr. Wilkinson and his brother, an Oxford man, who both take sketches well themselves” (273). Grant’s “Journal of a Three Weeks Tour, in 1797, through Derbyshire to the Lakes” appeared anonymously in Vol. 5 of William Mavor’s The British Tourists; or Traveller’s Pocket Companion, through England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland, 5 vols. (London: Newbery, 1798). [back]
23. Although Select Views is frequently described and cataloged as a folio, it was slightly larger than the traditional volume advertised as such. Later advertisements (e.g., fig. 7) promise the use of oversized “double Elephant” (or 41” x 27”) paper. Folded in half, this paper measured 20.5” x 13.5,” making it roughly 1.5” taller and wider than those found in the standard 12” x 19” folio. These large sheets help account for the series’ unusually wide margins. [back]
24. Rudolph Ackermann, the Regency’s leading publisher of engraved prints, became especially bullish on including letterpress descriptions after his enormous success with The Microcosm of London (1808–10). This popular series—the last number of which appeared on the same day, 1 Jan. 1810, as the first of Select Views—featured a more extensive letterpress than any previous Ackermann title. See John Ford, Rudolph Ackermann and the Regency World (Sussex: Warnham, 2018), ch. 7 (esp. pp. 98–101). [back]
25. This same notice appeared in the Eclectic Review for April 1809 and the May issues of, among others, the Literary Panorama, the Monthly Magazine, and the Scots Magazine. [back]
26. Now in the Wordsworth Trust archives, Wilkinson’s letter to Coleridge is reproduced in Owen and Smyser, Prose Works (2:124) and Reed, Middle Years (p. 671). Two details suggest this undated letter was written in early June 1809. First, Wilkinson reports having read “with much pleasure & interest” the first issue of Coleridge’s The Friend, which appeared on 1 June 1809. Second, in a separate letter dated 10 June 1809, Wordsworth conveys to the publisher of The Friend names and addresses for four new subscribers that Wilkinson had forwarded in his letter (Letters, 8: 17–18). In early June, Coleridge was away visiting a friend near Penrith, and he wouldn’t return to Grasmere until the 13th. It therefore appears Wordsworth opened Wilkinson’s letter in his housemate’s absence, as he would not have otherwise had the subscriber details he forwarded prior to Coleridge’s return. For Coleridge’s whereabouts during these weeks, see Reed, Middle Years, 430, and Richard Holmes, Coleridge: Darker Reflections, 1804–1834 (New York: Pantheon, 1998), 158–63. [back]
27. The Manchester-born Green befriended Wordsworth after moving to nearby Ambleside around 1800. His print series, Seventy-Eight Studies from Nature, began appearing on 1 Aug. 1809. [back]
28. Letters, 2:271. [back]
29. Owen and Smyser, Prose, 2:124. For similar interpretations, see Stephen Gill, William Wordsworth: A Life (Oxford: Oxford UP, 1989), 284; Barker, 280–81; and Peter Simonsen, Wordsworth and Word-Preserving Arts: Typographic Inscription, Ekphrasis and Posterity in the Later Work (Basingstoke: Palgrave, 2007), 17. [back]
30. See Letters, 2:282, 364, 367, and 376. Hardship, of course, is relative, and, it bears noting that, intent on preserving some semblance of gentility, the family employed at least two servants throughout these lean years. [back]
31. Letters, 2:385, 402, 406, 409–15. [back]
32. For the consistently disappointing sales of Wordsworth’s poetry, see Gill, Life, 258–59 and 266–67; John Worthen, The Life of William Wordsworth: A Critical Biography (Oxford: Wiley Blackwell, 2014), 368–69; and Letters, 2:282 and 3:8–9. [back]

35. Influential studies on these enduring myths of unworldly Romanticism include “The Romantic Artist,” ch. 2 in Raymond Williams’s Culture and Society: 1780–1950 (New York: Columbia UP, 1958), and Jerome McGann’s The Romantic Ideology: A Critical Investigation (Chicago: Chicago UP, 1983). [back]
36. Wordsworth’s letters (see 2:344–54, esp. 354) show how, during the very week when Wilkinson’s offer would have arrived, he was obsessively tracking, and carping about, the publication of The Convention of Cintra. The four Friend essays are “Letter to Mathetes” (published across 14 Dec. 1809 and 4 Jan. 1810), “Essay upon Epitaphs” (published 22 Feb. 1810), and two additional “Essays upon Epitaphs” not published until 1876 (Letters, 2:388n.). [back]
37. See Letters 2:3, 8, 90, 195, and 208 for Wordsworth’s interest in landscaping and the fine arts during this period. His “three callings” remark was reportedly made to the Rev. Robert Perceval Graves, who shared it with Christopher Wordsworth for inclusion in Memoirs of William Wordsworth (London: Moxon, 1851), 2:482. [back]
38. Letters, 2:271–72; The Journal of Elizabeth, Lady Holland, ed. Giles Stephen Holland Fox-Strangways, 2 vols. (London: Longmans, Green, and Co., 1908). Wordsworth may have exaggerated his actual progress to Lady Holland, as no evidence suggests he had made headway on a “manual to guide travelers” prior to their dinner. Her diary entry also valuably captures an embryonic version of what would become the Guide’s famous passages on house colors. Wordsworth “holds some opinions on picturesque subjects with which I completely differ,” she writes, “especially as to the effects produced by white houses on the sides of the hills; to my taste they produce a cheerful effect. He, on the contrary, would brown, or even black-work them; he maintained his opinion with a considerable degree of ingenuity. His objection was chiefly grounded upon the distances being confounded by the glare of white” (2:231). [back]
39. Noting that Wordsworth stayed mum until 1820 about his involvement with Select Views, Mary Moorman concludes, “No doubt this was because he thought meanly of the drawings and did not particularly wish his name to be associated with them” (William Wordsworth: A Biography, The Later Years 1803–1850, [Oxford: Oxford UP, 1965], 159). More broadly, Moorman misleadingly insinuates that Wordsworth, not Wilkinson, oversaw the series’ financing, marketing, and distribution. [back]
40. Although the OED dates the earliest use of “ghost writer” to 1927, Graves Glenwood Clark seems to self-consciously coin the term a few years earlier in “The Ghost Writer and His Story,” The Editor: The Journal of Information for Literary Workers 52.4 (25 Feb. 1920), 145. Surprisingly little has been published on the history of ghost-writing. It appears, however, to have emerged as a byproduct of the professionalization of authorship during the late eighteenth century. Samuel Johnson was among the first major authors to specialize in the craft, ghost-writing at least twenty-eight sermons (only two of which, however, were published). See James Gray, Johnson’s Sermons: A Study (Oxford: Oxford UP, 1972), 7–10. [back]
41. Knapp and Hulbert, Ghostwriting and the Ethics of Authenticity (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2017), vi. [back]
42. Letters, 2:364. [back]
43. Letters, 2:372. [back]
44. Letters, 2:404. [back]
45. See DCMS 68.3A and 68.3D at the Wordsworth Trust. Both manuscripts are undated and in Sara Hutchinson’s hand, with Wordsworth’s note to Wilkinson (“Herewith is matter for two more numbers . . . ”) superimposed over the header for “Section 2.” In his 1993 supplement to the Wordsworths’ Letters, Alan G. Hill tentatively dates William’s note on DCMS 68.3A to early March 1810, since his amanuensis, Sara Hutchinson, moved to her brother’s home in Wales in mid-March. Yet, in mentioning that Wilkinson had “only six months before you,” Wordsworth presumably meant that, while six of the twelve monthly instalments (i.e., Jan.–June) had shipped, six (i.e., July–Dec.) remained. If this reading is correct, he sent his manuscript and the inscribed note to Wilkinson sometime between late May (when the June installment was in print) and mid-June (before July’s was complete). This would confirm Hill’s alternate theory that Hutchinson copied the manuscript before leaving in mid-March and Wordsworth added his note later, when he “judged the moment right to send Wilkinson more copy” (Letters, 8:20). [back]
46. Letters, 8:25. For details on the gap between the intended and actual contents of Wordsworth’s descriptions, see Reed, Middle Years, 672, and Owen and Smyser, Prose Works, 2:126. [back]
47. For the serialization dates for specific parts of the letterpress, see the table at the end of Appendix 1 of this edition. [back]
48. Letters, 2:449. [back]
49. 15 Oct. 1820 letter to John Monkhouse in The Letters of Sara Hutchinson, ed. Kathleen Coburn (Toronto: U of Toronto P, 1954), 213—letter 11 in this edition’s appendix. [back]
50. While Wilkinson revised his sketches for the 1817 and 1821 editions of Select Views, he republished the letterpress exactly as it had appeared in 1810 (i.e., no revisions, same font and page layout, identical pagination). For details on the 1817 reissue, see Reed, A Bibliography, A10. The 1821 Select Views, a copy of which is held by the Wordsworth Trust, was advertised as follows in the Norfolk Chronicle for 18 Aug. 1821: “A limited number of sets of the Select Views in Cumberland, Westmoreland, and Lancashire from Drawings by the Rev. Joseph Wilkinson, revised and corrected from the Original Sketches are now ready for delivery, price in extra boards, 6l. 6s.” (3). [back]
51. Most collectors would have set aside the monthly installments of Select Views either at the agent bookshop or in the family library until all numbers had appeared. This helps explain the relative uniformity of surviving copies, which generally include all 48 engravings and follow the order prescribed on Wilkinson’s contents page (which shipped with the final number). For details on binding practices during this era, see Philip Gaskell, A New Introduction to Bibliography (Oxford: Oxford UP, 1972), esp. 146–53, 179–83, and 231–34; Nicholas Pickwoad, “Bookbinding in the in Eighteenth Century,” in The Cambridge History of the Book in Britain, Volume 5: 1695–1830, edited by Michael F. Suarez and Michael L. Turner (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 1999), 268–90; and Griffiths, The Print before Photography, 359–60. [back]
52. Between 1809 and 1812, Wordsworth returned to key themes from Select Views in two essays known today as the “Unpublished Tour” and “The Sublime and the Beautiful.” He left these pieces unfinished, however, when his 1812 pension from Lord Lonsdale and 1813 appointment as Distributor of Stamps gave him the financial freedom to return to poetry. Core ideas from both essays would inform later versions of the Guide. See Gill, Life, 295–96 and the version of both essays in Vol. 2 of Owen and Smyser’s Prose Works. [back]
53. Based on evidence he deems “neither abundant nor direct, but sufficient,” Reed suggests Wordsworth was “very probably back at work on a guide again, motivated by financial objectives, around November 1812” (Middle Years, 673–75). [back]
54. For more details on Wordsworth’s revisions, see our parallel-text chart and Owen and Smyser, Prose, 2:133–34. [back]
55. Of the 500 copies printed in 1820, 340 sold in the first year, 72 in the second, and 8 in the third. Sales essentially stalled at this point, and 30 copies were remaindered in 1834. See W. J. B. Owen, “Cost, Sales, and Profits of Longman’s Editions of Wordsworth,” The Library, 5th ser., 12.2 (1957): 101. [back]
56. See “Wordsworth’s River Duddon, and Other Poems,” British Review 16 (Sep. 1820), 52; “Wordsworth’s New Poems. The River Duddon; A Series of Sonnets: and other Poems, &c.,” Literary Gazette 166 (25 Mar. 1820), 203; and “Wordsworth’s River Duddon, &c.” Monthly Review 93 (Oct. 1820), 143. [back]
57. A Description of the Scenery of the Lakes in the North of England, 3rd ed. (London: Longman, 1822), 120. [back]
58. See, for instance, advertisements in the Literary Gazette, 1 July 1826, 415; the Monthly Literary Advertiser, 10 July 1826, 55; the Literary Gazette, 12 May 1827, 304; the Morning Journal, 23 May 1829, 1; the Literary Gazette, 21 Aug 1830, 551; the Age, 26 June 1831, 207; and the Courier, 16 July 1833, 1. [back]
59. Wordsworth netted an underwhelming £62.12.10 from the 1,500 copies of the 1822 and 1823 editions. Longman’s account books show 468 copies of the Guide selling in 1822, 113 in 1824, and 169 in 1825. Excepting 1829, when 120 copies sold, the publisher moved between 33 and 85 per year between 1826 and 1835. The unusual interest in the Guide well after its release speaks, in part, to its perceived utility. Most of Wordsworth’s poetry collections sold several hundred copies in the first two years but fewer than ten copies per year thereafter. See Owen, “Cost, Sales, and Profits,” 103. [back]
60. Compared to the £30 Longman spent on nationwide advertisements for the 1823 edition, Wordsworth’s new publishers set aside a minuscule £3.14 for advertising the fifth edition. Hudson reported to Wordsworth having advertised the new edition in six small-town Cumbrian newspapers: the Carlisle Journal, Carlisle Patriot, Kendal Gazette, Kendal Mercury, Whitehaven Pacquet, and Whitehaven Herald (Wordsworth Trust MS. WLMS 6/9/1). See also Owen, “Costs, Sales, and Profits,” 103 and 106. [back]
61. Wordsworth Trust MS. WLMS 6/9/1. [back]
62. Daniel Defoe, A Tour thro’ the Whole Island of Great Britain, Divided into Circuits or Journies, 3 vols. (London: n.p., 1724): 3:258. The most comprehensive survey of early books on Lake Country topography remains Peter Bicknell’s The Picturesque Scenery of the Lake District 1752–1855: A Bibliographical Study (Winchester: St. Paul’s Bibliographies, 1990). For how Wordsworth’s expanding popularity influenced the development of Victorian travel literature, see Saeko Yoshikawa’s William Wordsworth and the Invention of Tourism, 1820–1900 (Burlington: Ashgate, 2014), esp. 225–41. [back]
63. Letters, 4:393. “Laker” had been in use since at least 1798, when James Plumptre wrote The Lakers: A Comic Drama, a gentle satire of Keswick-centered tourism and the fashion for botany. In 1805, Windermere resident Richard Watson, Bishop of Llandaff, explained to a friend that “Lakers” was “the denomination by which we distinguish those who come to see our country.” More specifically, he suggested, it was reserved for “idle persons who love laking” (Anecdotes of the Life of Richard Watson, 2 vols. [London: Cadell and Davies, 1817], 2:269). [back]
64. We put “wilderness” in quotes because, as Wordsworth was well aware, the Lake District was hardly an untouched preserve, even before eighteenth-century tourists took interest in it. Humans had long inhabited and shaped the region. For Wordsworth, then, preserving the landscape meant holding on to and enhancing its character as produced by traditional ways of life and the mediating power of taste. Throughout the Guide, readers find significant tension between “nature” and “culture.” Several scholars listed in our annotated bibliography have addressed this tension and other complications attending Wordsworth’s environmentalism. [back]
65. Wordsworth, Kendal and Windermere Railway: Two Letters Re-printed from The Morning Post (Kendal: Branthwaite and Son, 1844), 7. [back]
66. Letters, 4:303. [back]
67. See especially the opening of “Section Third” in the 1835 edition. In the first edition of 1810, Wordsworth had spoken of events from “within the last forty years,” making 1770, his birth year, the point of departure. This blurring of regional history and his own lifespan connected the Guide and the landscape it celebrates to the biographical myth underlying Wordsworth’s poetic project (see Gill, Life, 285). [back]
68. For a comprehensive history of Lake District literature prior to Wordsworth, see Peter Bicknell’s The Picturesque Scenery of the Lake District, 1752–1855: A Bibliographical Study (Winchester: St. Paul’s Bibliographies, 1990). [back]
69. Dr. Syntax was serialized in Ackermann’s Poetical Magazine between 1809 to 1811, making it contemporaneous with another Ackermann publication, Wilkinson’s Select Views. [back]
70. A Description of the Lake at Keswick and the Adjacent Country in Cumberland, Communicated in a Letter to a Friend, by a Late Popular Writer (Kendal: J. Ashburner, 1770), 5. [back]
71. Bicknell, Picturesque Scenery, 1. [back]
72. Wordsworth here echoed the influential editor of West’s Guide, William Cockin, who admitted that Gray’s journal offered little of what readers might call “fine writing” but insisted that those who prized trustworthy description and “elegant simplicity of narrative” would consider it a welcome companion to their travels (in West, A Guide to the Lakes, 2nd ed. [London: Richardson and Urquhart, 1780], 199). [back]
73. Gray, quoted in Thomas West, A Guide to the Lakes in Cumberland, Westmorland, and Lancashire, 2nd ed. (1780), 199 and 212. [back]
74. West, A Guide to the Lakes (London: Richardson and Urquhart, 1778), 15–16. [back]
75. Ian Ousby, The Englishman’s England (London: Cambridge UP, 1990), 138–39. [back]
76. Letters, 2:404. [back]
77. On Wordsworth as founding figure for national parks, see Stephen Gill, Wordsworth and the Victorians (Oxford: Clarendon, 1998), 260. [back]
78. Bicknell, Illustrated Wordsworth’s Guide to the Lakes, 7. [back]
79. See Julia S. Carlson, “Prose Mesurée in the Lakes Tour and Guide: Quoting and Recalibrating English Blank Verse,” European Romantic Review 20, no. 2 (April 2009): 227–36. [back]
80. “Wordsworthshire” seems to have been coined by Harvard professor James Russell Lowell (see the unsigned biographical sketch he contributed to The Poetical Works of William Wordsworth [7 vols., Boston: Little, Brown, and Company, 1854, xxxviii], material later reworked as “Wordsworth” in Among My Books, 2nd Series [Boston: James R. Osgood, 1876, 240]). However, the term is essentially synonymous with “Wordsworth Country” and other common designations of the Lake District’s literary landscape that developed across the nineteenth and into the early twentieth century. Compare “Scott-land,” “Burns Country,” and similar inventions of the Victorian travel and literary heritage industries. [back]
81. Letters, 2:271. [back]
82. The “poetry of nature” phrase originates in Coleridge’s account of the genesis of Lyrical Ballads: “During the first year that Mr. Wordsworth and I were neighbours, our conversations turned frequently on the two cardinal points of poetry, the power of exciting the sympathy of the reader by a faithful adherence to the truth of nature, and the power of giving the interest of novelty by the modifying colours of imagination. The sudden charm, which accidents of light and shade, which moonlight or sunset diffused over a known and familiar landscape, appeared to represent the practicability of combining both. These are the poetry of nature” (Biographia Literaria, [London: Rest Penner, 1817], vol. 2, 1). For Wordsworth’s discussion of “imagination” in the note to “The Thorn,” see the 2nd edition of Lyrical Ballads (London: Longman, 1800, vol. 1, 211–12). [back]
83. See his letters to the Morning Post, published together in slightly revised and expanded form as the pamphlet Kendal and Windermere Railway: Two Letters Re-printed from The Morning Post (1844), 6. [back]
84. Kendal and Windermere Railway, 19. [back]
